												So here's this game I played several times on the PS2, and it is SO FUN. PC is no exception.People may have seen the camera on the box art back in the day and said to themselves "Ew! Camera in the gameplay, no way!" Sure the camera is sometimes a necessary part of the game, but combat and stealth are major gameplay elements that shouldn't be overlooked.The story centres on Jade and Pey'j, in a strange world where half-animal people walk around on two legs and talk. For example Pey'j has a definite boar-like appearance. The world is under siege from the Domz armada, and the Alpha Sections are there to stop them. During an attack Jade discovers she's out of credits and her lighthouse shield power is cut off. In an effort to make some credits she takes on a photography job for the local science centre, and through a turn of events ends up working for a secret underground movement called the Iris Network.The plot is fairly straightforward - you go on missions looking for evidence, once you find the evidence you take photos of it, and then you get the hell outta there. The missions are few and large, and the best way to approach it is to go sneaky stealth mode on everything. It is possible to attack your enemies too, but you will have a hard time.Gameplay combat is all 3rd-person, but not all of it is melee. There are battles on the water inside your 'tugboat', and towards the end of the game there is even a spaceship battle, which I thoroughly enjoyed. Enemies hit hard in melee combat though, so it pays to grab all the health upgrades you can find. These can be manually distributed to your companion too if you think they need it. As already mentioned, subterfuge is your friend - you will have more fun with sneak attacks and trickery than trying to face-tank your way though the game.Other gameplay elements include speed-races to get your stolen credits back, minigames (that game in the Akuda Bar is badass hard), finding all the species to photograph for more credits, finding all the pearls for more vehicle upgrades. There are a couple of foot-chases too, to add whipped cream to an already delicious cake of a game.So how delicious is it? Well the music is a blast for starters. It has a wonderful style to it, melodious and alien. Well-suited to the game. The graphics are a little bland but good - with a main character like Jade it makes sense there's a bit of a green theme to it. Voice-actors have been cast well, there is a lot of great voice-acting in the game and it helps to suspend disbelief, helping immersion and reinforcing our empathy towards the characters.Highly recommended to anyone that loves stealth, a great story, or just wants to try something new. The hours I've played it on PC are not representative of my total hours (PC and PS2). Worth it just for the soundtrack!

												Hands down one of the best Action-Adventure game ive played to this date, I loved the charecters and story and this review will tell you why I personally enjoyed each aspect of the game. (Ubisoft release BGaE 2 Please!) Before you question that I don't have the hours played on this game I have played the ps2 version and the HD remastered verson on the Xbox 360 and completed it on each platform. What does the game offer in terms of what genre it is The game is an Action/Adventure game with elements of Stealth and puzzle solving. The game doesnt throw you into battles all the time and most battles you can avoid by running away. The stealth in this game is almost completely optional unless theres a drone in the room, this drone only targets intruders when spotted and will instantly kill you which enforces you to be stealthy. There are puzzles to solve and most of them are easy to do like for example you have to redirect light beams to go to a certain area to access the next area. StoryWarning: This story is not set on the planet Earth, its a factional planet called HillysWhen i first started playing I didn't know what to expect when i first played but the story grabbed me about how the population was threatened by aliens called the Domz and how they attack every so often. When you first get to play you are thrown into combat stright away and the game doesn't hold your hand when it comes to showing combat, it shows a small text at the bottom showing what you press to attack but thats it, the enemy won't wait. As you play through the game you realise that the so called protectors are your enemy and the rebel organisation is actually the good guys. There is 3 dungon like places you go into to sneak around gathering infomation about what they are actually doing and exposeing them for what they do. I could go into more detail about the story but I don't want to spoil the story MusicEDIT: I almost forgot about the music, ill tag it hereThe music in the game is one of the best composed soundtrack. Each track suits the time it is played, an example when the main character gets depressed and the soundtrack suits it as they use viloin as well as low notes to express the feelings. There are other times but its worth to play a demo of this game or to play the game to get the full feeling for the game. CharectersThere is One main character that you control called Jade, she is the reporter and also an animal documenter (as thats a main way of obtaining units which is the currency of the game) and she looks after the orphans of Hillys and she has to leave them to do her missions which sets up the plot of the game. She has two companions throughout the game.The first one, Pey'j is her uncle who helps looking after the orphans and is also a mechanic. He doesnt stay for long as he is captured at the factory when you are finding out about what the alpha sections are doing. Pey'j has a special ability which allows him to slam onto the ground which throws up enemys to allow you to attack them and use them as projectiles. After the main plot is developed Pey'j gets a field ability where he can cut through metal fences which allows you to access areas or to get further through the main story.When you save Double H at the factory he joins you as the other companion throughout the rest of the game and he helps you through the remainder of the game.  Double H has a specal abilty where he uses his hammer to throw up enemys just like Pey'j but he has a field abilty where he will charge head first (helmet equipped of course) to knock down metal barred doors. What was the final boss likeObviously with a title like this i shouldn't need to tell you that there will be spoliers but i'll put it here anyway.SPOLIER ALERTSPOLIER ALERTI have warned you. Don't complain if I spoil too much. The final boss was unique as it had you thinking on your feet as you attack, he steals your uncle which leaves you with yourself and Double H, after killing the clones of your uncle Double H is taken as well and you have to fight the clones of Double H by your self and the clones keep telling you that you should give up, which isn't a option. Adventually you will be weakened as the boss says and will reverse your directional controls regardless of your settings, you can not go into the settings and change them because the game will keep them reversed, im not sure if you can go into the game with reversed directional controls and for it to be flipped. This is unique as i havent seen any other final boss do this. If your a controller user (from the ps2 or xbox 360/PS3 games) you could flip the controller itself making it slightly easier. I will not spoil how the game ends, ill leave that to you Was there anything i didn't like?There wasn't much I didn't like. I loved each part of the game. I guess that the most difficult parts would be when you had a drone in the room forceing stealth as it was in a difficult room where the guards are placed in difficult spots to get pass, for example placed at the doorway you need to get out at.Do I recommend this gameDefently as it will give you hours of fun as the main game lasts for about 7 to 8 hours without getting all the collectables, if your a completionist then it would take about 11 to 14 hours tops to get everything.

Short version: 92%Beyond Good & Evil mixes many gameplay elements to create a fun, adventurous, yet surprisingly serious storyline about the struggles of a reporter who slowly uncovers the sinister plot against her home planet. Although it gained some recognition in the past five years, this game is still one of the most underappreciated sparkling gems of this century.Long version:Beyond Good & Evil was praised by both the press and players alike, yet it is still a perpetual resident on any list that collects the best rarely known games from the past 10-15 years or so. At first glance, these ratings are difficult to justify – after all, the game is a strange hodgepodge of various genres: puzzle, platformer, stealth, 3D brawler, treasure hunt, with some driving and racing on top.While these mixed-genre games rarely work, somehow the designers managed to keep all of these elements together in a tight knot. After getting used to the controls (a controller helps), we find a game with great mechanics, astonishing levels of large variety, and a small world that constantly offers some activity between the platforming stages, but not in a distracting manner.The final selling point is the story: we follow the adventures of Jade, a reporter and caretaker of some recently orphaned children. She gradually gets entangled in the war between her home planet and the invading aliens, only to discover the sinister truth behind the attacks, the recent kidnappings, and her own past.Despite the serious nature of the story, both the aesthetics and the writing tries to be light-hearted and fun, giving a great sense of adventure even when you are discussing battle plans in the back room of a bar. The cast does a wonderful job of delivering some memorable lines, elevating Beyond Good & Evil into a classic status, recommended for anyone who never had the pleasure of playing it.

Are you ready to transcend morality and petty social convention?Though disappointed initially by the lack of Nietzsche, Beyond Good & Evil delivers a good action-adventure game that delves into some surprisingly dark themes and mature content. The beautiful visuals really have helped with how finely the game has aged over the years, with lighting in particular creating some stunning vistas and stellar views of the various landscapes and colourful underground. A gritty approach to science fiction, BGE follows the young photojournalist Jade, a caretaker of sorts for a bunch of ragtag kids and orphans on the planet of Hyllis, along with her long-time friend and mentor Pey’J. Futuristic but with noticeable fantasy and steampunk influences, the on-going war between the supposedly benevolent Alpha Sections regime and the “DomZ” – a seemingly endless alien force – in the backdrop to an otherwise peaceful, everyday setting gradually begins to appear as more than it seems. Pulled into a momentous conspiracy cover-up, you’re tasked to reveal the truth and ignite a revolution.Gameplay is broken down into a mixture of free-roaming, puzzles and stealth sections. There’s a decent enough amount of content for you to try outside of missions, but most of it generally comes down to forgettable mini-games and pearl hunting. The stealth system is very simplistic but works well for what it sets out to do, even if you’ll find yourself asking how on earth you managed to sneak past that guard without being detected.In terms of puzzles, they’re generally straightforward to do and rely on grasping the layout of the level’s environment, though may appear bewildering in design at times. Any more than this I can’t really comment on, considering my own legendary impatience and lack of skill in solving video game puzzles. Be ready to add a bit more on to the average completion time if you’re in a similar position. The art style is great, with a nice vibrancy and cartoonish aesthetic to it, and character models equally so. The sound design is fantastic, with the score in particular really creating a moody, sci-fi ambiance. Some of it’s almost reminiscent of Kelly Bailey’s work for Half-Life and suits the game perfectly. However, BGE does suffer from the typical trappings of the genre’s design. The fixed camera positions can be a nightmare at times, especially in vehicle sections, and this has a rather significant effect on not only basic navigation but the otherwise smooth and relatively satisfying gameplay. Jade has some great moves in combat, (think of a more dexterous equivalent to Monkey’s style in Enslaved: Odyssey to the West), but the camera and constantly changing direction of movement controls can be immensely frustrating to wrestle with. Also, facial animations and lip-syncing doesn’t occur for in-game/contextual dialogue… another odd drawback. Some other more minor issues generally come down to noticeable clipping and some A.I. quirks but overall the technical aspects are quite good.The biggest failing of Beyond Good & Evil is in the constant grind that is required to progress throughout the main story. Being an older adventure game and thus featuring the obligatory unlock currency system, BGE requires you to upgrade the central hovercraft vehicle with the collectible pearls that are scattered throughout the map and various levels. While most of these you’ll come by incidentally, completing tasks or through purchases, you will eventually be required to painfully grind to receive the next unlock, most likely at the end of the game, where this shouldn’t be happening at the most. (♥♥♥♥ing hell, that final boss fight was brutal.)While I can understand this age-old trope of game design, it really detracts from an otherwise enjoyable game when the story itself is locked off to you. There is no cheat code or other way to bypass these mind-numbing sections outside of a custom editor, so the grind is unfortunately inevitable. You might argue that this was done to encourage exploration, but the game was already worth delving into and shouldn't have to be forced upon players either. The best way to avoid it would be to just carefully scour the levels early on and try and complete miscellaneous tasks wherever possible. In all honesty, I don’t usually go for these kinds of games but found Beyond Good & Evil to be really enjoyable. If you’re a fan of the likes of Tomb Raider, Zelda, Shadow of the Colossus or Devil May Cry, you’ll be right at home here with a good experience all-round on offer, totalling around 10 or so hours of play. You can also remind yourself of what Ubisoft used to be.It may be in development hell, but whenever the second game comes, it’ll be worth it. Thumbs up.

-Quick Review-Beyond Good and Evil is Ubisoft's under-rated-masterpiece, it was first released on the PlayStation 2 on November 11, 2003. The beautiful Music was Composed by Christophe Héral.Beyond Good and Evil is by far the most beautiful, outstanding game I ever played on the PS2, and when I saw it was available on Steam I exploded. There are many games that we as gamers 'play and forget'. Beyond Good and Evil is one of the games I will never forget.-Video Review!-


YouTube™ Video: Atratzu Reviews: Beyond Good and Evil - Ain't Morality something? 

			Views: 465		

			Atratzu Reviews Beyond Good and Evil, for the Playstation 2, Xbox, GameCube, and Steam PC port. This is one of the RPG's he speaks most highly of, so it's befitting this is the first game he reviews!		

-Detailed breakdown review-Story: Beyond Good and Evil's Protagonist is a bright young woman named Jade. Jade is an avid martial artist, photographer and investigative reporter. She has been staying with her 'Uncle' Pay'j (A pig/boar-like biped, whom is acting as Jade's Guardian) to help take care of orphans at their lighthouse home.Jade and Pay'j are on the mining planet “Hillys”. Hillys is under siege by an extraterrestrial group known as the “DomZ”, the DomZ are skeleton-reaper-like-aliens whom abduct and drain the life from their victims. Recently a group known as “The Alpha Sections” have taken up residence on Hillys. The Alpha Sections have sworn to defend the population of Hillys from these devastating DomZ attacks.


Just an awesome moment in the begining of the game. 
A Screenshot of Beyond Good & Evil
By: Atratzu




Gameplay: You play the game as Jade, in a third person camera view, the game is broken down into two modes: combat mode and stealth mode. (Side note: There is much more to the game than that, sometimes you need to take pictures, solve puzzles, figure out riddles, play mini games, and have dialogue with other NPC's.)When in combat, Jade wields a special Bo Staff known as a “Jō”; Jade preforms strikes, flips, and power attacks while in combat mode. If you were unsuccessful in sneaking past enemies you can fight your way through many parts of the game. However there is definitely an emphasis on stealth rather than fighting.When in stealth, Jade sneaks and rolls, there are oftentimes alternative paths to sneak around guards, other times you need to distract guards by creating a diversion to take them away from their posts, while you sneak past.


Beyond Good & Evil 
A Screenshot of Beyond Good & Evil
By: Atratzu




A final note I should make, is the console to PC port wasn't quite perfect; the camera angle is sometimes a little bit awkward, but you eventually get used to the limitations and controls; Beyond Good and Evil is still very playable.Achievements: There are no achievements in the game, however there are extra things to collect while playing. You can take pictures of all the animals in the game, and collect all the pearls, and find every M-disks. Price: Beyond Good and Evil is priced at $9.99, my first play through I unlocked everything before beating the game (I took my sweet time about it, and it took about 9-11 hours) the game can easily take anywhere from 6-8 hours to complete.When I was younger playing this game on the PS2; I remember that I almost beat this whole game in a day. My parrents left the house in the late morning and I started playing Beyond Good and Evil, when they got back that evening I was still playing. Needless to say, they were not pleased with my binge-playing-habits.http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=511832156Conclusion: Seriously, just buy and play this game.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update August 29, 2015:Spelling fix, by Angfucious. Posted: April 6
												It's funny how this game is nearly 15 years old now, but feels more relevant than ever. Beyond Good & Evil is basically a game about journalism, and how important a role it plays in society. Playing it in 2017, it was almost eerie to see how relevant it felt to current events. That theme and the way its presented throughout the story feels like unique territory for gaming, making this a really special game. On that merit alone, I'd recommend this to anyone who's interested in seeing how a big studio game can effectively tackle real world issues like any other art form.Though, it's important to know what you're getting into. This game is from 2003, and it really shows. While playing it, I couldn't stop noticing all of the outdated trends of the era used here. There's obligatory stealth, arbitrary, collecting, generic Zelda-esque action, and goofy PS2-platformer humor that doesn't quite mesh with the game's tone (it feels like someone shoved Ratchet & Clank's jokes into a completely different game). None of it is purely bad, but it certainly doesn't age well making certain sections of it a slog. It's also a very buggy game (again, as you may expect). In one of the biggest cutscenes in the game, the dialogue track completely cut out for me, so I missed a pretty major section.If all of that sounds like it'd drive you crazy, then I wouldn't recommend it. But I still maintain that there's enough value in this to warrant checking it out. I think it's one of the more effective studio games I've played in terms of how meaningful it feels. This should be at the center of a video game museum, showcasing how the medium of games can do more than simply entertain us.

												Still, way to few people talk about this game. Speculations about the sequel change frequently and make it all the harder to play this game time and time again. Not because it isn't fun, but because you want more - you don't want this to be all.BG&E is a game which I could pick up and play to 100% completion any second - and I would enjoy myself. I played it first on my gamecube and when it released on Steam it was an instabuy and an instaplay. Start to finish. And there was hardly any minute, nay second in which I didn't like what the game had to offer. Before I get to the game itself, just a little insight into my perspective towards a special kind of games (feel free to skip):This game reminds me of the good ol' Rareware. Back in the 90ies and early 2000's before they sold their soul to Microsoft. Games made with love, attention to detail, heart and (and I can't believe that this is a trademark that needs to be pointed out) color. Games like Banjo-Kazooie, Conkers Bad Fur Day and weirdly enough this Ubisoft-Game stick out to me not just gameplay-wise, but also visually. They are bright where they need to be and dark when it is necessary - but they always ooze charme and liveliness. And to be fair - in its catalog of ♥♥♥♥♥♥ and unpolished games, Ubisoft does have some amazing titles - Child of Light and Rayman come to mind. All these aforementioned games fall into a special kind of category for me. They all feel different and distinct from each other, but still weirdly similar. They all share the high quality anyways. But hey, maybe that is just me.About BG&E itself:Beyond good and evil is an action adventure mix without any outstanding design decisions, but everything that is in the game, is very well implemented, while still being kinda basic. There is a simple combat system, which doesn't reach the levels of a spectacle fighter - reminiscent of Starfox Adventures. There is a stealth system, but it isn't as deep as the likes of Metal Gear, Splinter Cell or Thief. There is some sense of Open-World-Exploration, but please don't expect GTA or Skyrim. There is photography, but (sadly) no Prof. Oak to evaluate your skills regarding capturing Snorlax' butt on polaroid. And there are racing-sequences, which...well they are rather tight actually - I lik'em.This game gives you a bit of everything in bitesized chunks and delivers a quite well presented story on the side. It is vast, but not intimidating. You can actually complete it 100% without doing a lot of unnecessary walking and searching - yet it feels rewarding. IMHO this is a game that you need to play to experience its appeal firsthand. Don't read about it, don't watch a Let's play - play it. It is really well polished, casts some memorable characters and, apart from the overall length of the game, does not leave much to be desired.

Even though the story was underwhelming the most standout part of this game, and the most enjoyable, is definitely the 100% believable female protagonist. It’s really nice to be able to play a woman who isn’t overly sexualized or a stereotypical manly, badass female. Unlike so many other female protagonist Jade is written like she’s a real, well rounded person. More writers need to play this game so they can learn how to write realistic characters, both female and male.

												Firstly, I didn't have a chance to play this when it originally came out and I also don't have too much experience with the 3rd person action adventure genre, so this opinion is relatively nostalgia or genre prejudice free.My issues with the game are mostly related to technical difficulties when attempting to get it up an running:  It'll always complain that your display drivers are out of date when launching (at least on an ATI card)  Audio goes off sync if you don't run it on a single core affinity  Your display settings need to be correct to avoid texture flickering  No out of box controller support for smoother analogue movementProbably something a patch or two could fix but they seem to have abandoned this one. You could also work around the controller issue by mapping the buttons using a 3rd party software such as JoyToKey, but you can't make it analogue though. I played this on keyboard and mouse due to that limitation and it's not bad, I just would've liked to play on the couch in Big Picture mode.Apart from those technical issues I could say that everything else about the game is good. The story and the characters are likeable and well-written. I particularly liked Uncle Pey'j, who is probably now one of my favourite sidekick characters in all games. Voice acting was pretty much spot on for each character, maybe little on a campy side with different accents and all that, but as long as it fits.. Same could be said about the music.I was a little worried that the early 2000s 3D graphics haven't aged well, but luckily my worries were in vain: Especially character movement and facial animations have stood the test of time and overall the game is still a pleasure to look at.I wasn't really a fan of the face to face combat sequences, which occasionally just turned into mashing fests with little to no idea which enemy I was targeting. Your character, Jade, also locks into enemies which can make her a bit hard to control in combat. Stealth sections were a nice change of pace though, and I didn't have too much trouble with the camera that seems to have been an issue for others.Solid fun for 10+ hours. I'm joining the group of people waiting for the sequel.

As philosophical as the title book was (Nietzche, don't get much more philosophical!), this story hits pretty close. But for you gameplay oriented people out there, this game is still good. It takes a bit of time to get used to antiquated controls and glitches, as this game was FAR smaller than most modern ones, but it created many of the engines later used. The camera support is very nice, the combat is fairly set up (but simple), but the majority of the game relies on caring about the world and the story, so if you like a good tale? Play this game. Help make them WANT to make the sequel we all need.

												One of the best games I've ever played..(If you just want to see my rating of this game, scroll right down to the bottom)I once bought this game, almost ten years ago retail. Never managed to finish it back then, cue to my computer crashing. The new one couldn't handle the disc..But now, steam has it, and I finally got to finishing it.Great story, great gameplay, has some stealth, racing, photographing, good dungeons, puzzle solving, amongst other things. It has some camera issues though, you might get annoyed by the fact that the camera is a bit hard to handle sometimes.Overall, I've had a great experience. The story and characters are all great and well-made, and the gameplay is well done although you might think "photographing as a gameplay element, what?"It is a bit shorter than many modern day games though, since back then you couldn't fit all that much onto a disc so it couldn't grow as massive as it wanted. (what I mean is, don't expect a twenty-hour long odyssey from this, I got through the whole game in just seven hours).For those who may be wondering, this game does not have multiplayer, it is singleplayer only. Meaning no versus, co-op or other such things.However, it is a bit poorly ported to the newer OS-versions, meaning that it will probably not be fully functional straight-off. Graphical and sound issues are the most common problems, and for some users it doesn't even start. However, ti did start for me, and the graphics bugs I fixed by turning off "HW vertex processing" in the advanced settings of the game's startup menu. The sound issue I've heard is related to multi-core, and mostly fixed by telling the game to use only one core. Still, I would recommend that you turn on subtitles, just in case. (it doesn't always work flawlessly with the voice, occasionally some pieces have been known to disappear..)Still, though, a really great game. To summarise, you should really consider buying this straight up, right now, if you don't mind a few problems, many which are quite easily fixed for some people. Of course, since these bugs vary from player to player I cannot know which ones you are going to have (for me only the graphical issues, along with some occasional missing sound in dialogue or music, were present. The repeating voice bug, was not) so therefore I will not take these bugs into consideration when rating this.If I disregard the problems that arrived when getting this to newer OS, this would get a solid 9/10 from me.Updated to remove a spelling error.

content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												Beyond Good and Evil is a 2003 Stealth Action-Adventure game developed by Ubisoft Montpellier, the studio behind the Rayman series and also responsible for original titles like From Dust. Montpellier, as a creative powerhouse, delivered Beyond Good and Evil to critical acclaim, but devastatingly poor sales have infamously seen the sequel perpetually delayed.This is a horrible port, and you should not buy it. Beyond Good and Evil is not a perfect game. This is the only version of it I've played, so my experience is not all encompassing. However, I felt that most, if not all, of the problem with the game stemmed from what a horrendous port this is. It controls absolutely awful, because for a game that is designed solely for gamepads, it dictates that you use the keyboard and mouse. Trying to steer Jade while clicking away in haphazard combos isn't fun at all, along with common mishaps like sticking to walls and desperately waggling the mouse in radial-based menus like an idiot. There is no gamepad support for this game whatsoever, outside of using a clunky 3rd-party program like Xpadder. So that means when the game restricts you camera to a 2D plane, you just have to deal with it. When it decides to wrench your camera away for you for no apparent reason, you just have to deal with it. When you're desperately wrenching the mouse while janking the hovercraft with the WASD keys to get it around corners, you just have to deal with it.Those are just the control issues. Even after disabling a certain amount of options to get the game running at above a powerpoint rate (note: simply lowering the settings made the game perform even worse) I had constant plummets in framerate and constant graphical glitches. This port (not by Montpellier) makes Ubisoft's recent debacles look good.It is, however, a decent game. The gameplay is shallow, and the amount of distractions in the disappointingly small hub-world one-note, but the game is carried by the amazing art style and music. The art style speaks for itself, and the music is worth tracking down if you can. While not sold on the game's cult classic status, the game is a solid casual Action Adventure that doesn't demand much in the way of attention and delivers on the premise plenty. I'm not recommending this, not because you shouldn't play this, but because you shouldn't play this version. Play the HD version, emulate a console version, by Jove even dig out a sixth gen system and track down a physical copy if you're truly dedicated to playing this game and seeing what the hype is all about.Playing the Steam version of Beyond Good and Evil will only sour you on an already hard to sell game.

												Beyond Good and Evil is pretty much a hidden gem, imo. I was too young to really play it during its original run, but I heard some good reviews about it, so I decided to pick up the PC version to see what was up.Right off the bat, BG&E is definately a beautiful game for something from 2003; the artstyle kinda helped it to age a littttleee bit better. Also oh my god, the soundtrack. Good stuff. The game is ahort at about 8 to 10 hours if you just power through it, so it's definately a game I'd reccomend to people looking for something to spend a weekend with, but there is a bit of stuff for completionists to do, (namely snappig some pictures of Hillyan wildlife that you might notta caught the first time around, and searching for all the pearls in game) and for that, I'm actually gonna be playing this a second time through!Gameplay on foot consists of a lotttaaa stealth. I don't really find the combat to be something to really write home about, but there's a lot of varied gameplay going on like hoverboat races, and some chases on foot and in vehicle. Overall, the game kinda tries its hand at pretty much everything, which is admirable, but it makes it so nothing really is as stellar as it coulda been. Not saying it's bad, just some elements of gameplay are better than others and everyone's gonna kinda have some elements that pop out a lil more to them than others.Overall, good game with a lotta varied gameplay that makes the 8-10 hours you'll spend on just the campaign interesting with a distinct art style and an A+ soundtrack. If the store description or any gameplay footage piques your interest, you'll probably like Beyond Good and Evil. A word of warning though, it's glitchy on modern OS's, especially Windows 8 and 10. I personally made this more playable by running the .exe in compatibility mode set on XP service Pack 3, but stilllllll had some minor audio and graphical glitches. Community discussion page offers some more fixes if you're looking to get it a little closer to the original, but if you're not in the mood for fiddling around, there's and HD version on XBL and PSN~

Not saying it's bad, just some elements of gameplay are better than others and everyone's gonna kinda have some elements that pop out a lil more to them than others.Overall, good game with a lotta varied gameplay that makes the 8-10 hours you'll spend on just the campaign interesting with a distinct art style and an A+ soundtrack. If the store description or any gameplay footage piques your interest, you'll probably like Beyond Good and Evil. A word of warning though, it's glitchy on modern OS's, especially Windows 8 and 10. I personally made this more playable by running the .exe in compatibility mode set on XP service Pack 3, but stilllllll had some minor audio and graphical glitches. Community discussion page offers some more fixes if you're looking to get it a little closer to the original, but if you're not in the mood for fiddling around, there's and HD version on XBL and PSN~

content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												Obviously surprising to most readers of this review, I didn't like the game. Please read all of it before bashing it though. It seems like everybody and their mother claims this game to be one of the best and beg for a sequel. I disagree. I only finished the game for the first time, never played it before. Maybe if I played it when younger I'd have some nostalgic factor or something, but that wouldn't actually mean the game is good... because the game is just not that good.The game, first off, is really, really simple, which isn't something I mean negatively. There's many simple modern games I enjoy, like Fable, so that isn't a bad point. The problem is that all of the simple "pieces" don't really work as expected. Before getting into the game, just a quick brush on graphics and such, though those don't really sway my opinion of a game. The graphics weren't bad, rough in places, but overall pretty decent for years back. The sound, on the other hand, was only okay. People seem to love the soundtrack, but all in all it was pretty average and had nothing exciting.The only song that stood out to me was out on the sea early in the game, the peaceful one reused at the beginning of the credits. It was really nice and I loved that one. Besides songs, the dialogue was decent. Audio sync didn't really cause many problems for me, only once or twice.Now, onto the game. The characters were all lackluster. I didn't really care about any of them, even the kids. The only one I liked was Pey'j. Jade didn't really stand out as a special protagonist, though I did feel a little twinge at a couple places near the end (mostly due to Pey'j). The kids were really only used at the beginning and end... and the same goes for Secundo. And Double H was sooooooo annoying. I really, really hated him. His voice and style was the most generically annoying possible.When it came to the NPCs in terms of gameplay, it was a waste. They served virtually no purpose other than to move around a couple puzzles and to bash their special ability during combat. But they served to make combat more annoying. They just stood around, got attacked, and got pinned to the ground. I wanted to give them PA-1's, but I needed the health usually! Friendly fire made it worse, because they just stood in my way and often I would take off half a heart because they'd get hit.Boss fights weren't good except for the final two bosses. All of the others were so simple and easy that I beat them all in less than 90 seconds each, some even less than 1 minute, because most of them were usually bashing the same pattern without thought. The first boss you could even beat without being touched, and without any effort.The controls in the game were pretty wobbly, usually because of the camera, which would bounce around. In most of the levels, the confines were relatively cramped, so the camera bounced all over for me. I'd be seeing through walls or the ground, and could barely keep things focused. If you walk near certain walls, the camera would jump 180 degrees, so during combat, it was even more terrible. I'd often end up hitting random things or thin air.Stealth wasn't that special. It was semi-enjoyable, but in some places the controls and camera made it worse. In one level (I think the Slaughterhouse? Or the one before it), there was sneaking through a foggy area, but it took me several tries to get through. It was really simple in idea, but my camera got stuck and I was always looking into the ground and at Zoey, all in the fog, so I could see nothing. It kept moving even if I centered the camera, so I could barely see the enemies. Other places were relatively annoying too, and all in all it just wasn't that fun or special.The story was pretty generic, really. Oh no, people are betrayed and getting abducted by aliens? That's pretty much all it amounted to the entire game, except for the last 5 minutes. But because I lost interest by that point, the last 5 minutes of revealings didn't make me care any more or want a sequel. The aspect of using a camera as a special spy was interesting at first, but everything was generally repetitive, so nothing special.Lastly, exploration was a bummer. I expected there to be a bit more to the world. I didn't expect something crazy... but there really wasn't much at all. The 4 races, meh. The 4 looter's caverns, meh. I mean, I did them all, and they were okay, but not much else opened up in the world as the game progressed. Only a couple more dungeon-like areas, but most were short.And the biggest annoying part of that... the city. I really, really liked the looks of the city going into it at first. I expected it to open up more throughout the game and was excited about it. You get a city pass and I thought, finally! But you move like 50 more feet and hit another wall. So basically, for a decently-sized city, you get to explore none of it. They could have really made it bigger. A few alleys was really disappointing.Anyway, everything culminated into a disappointment. I'm not complaining because of overhyping; I'm just stating that the game was generally flawed in almost all of its aspects. I have absolutely no desire to replay it, while there are many other games I have replayed or will replay through the years.

												Aesthetics and music are top notch. The story is so-so.However, I must say that the core gameplay is either mediocre or downright annoying. Most of it is thanks to the camera. What happens is that, in some sections (combat & stealth), the camera is fixed at an angle, but you can still move it inside its axis. This creates a few undesirable situations, where you're fighting multiple enemies and the camera keeps snapping forward, or the camera angle doesn't actually show what's ahead (in stealth sections). The main problem is that your controls change when the camera changes, so an abrupt change can make the camera keep snapping forward and backwards, making you run up to enemies you don't want to fight.The stealth gameplay in this is very simple. Enemy saw you? Run to another room. Got into a fight with patrols? Pray the camera doesn't keep getting in your way.The story starts pretty good, but after mid-point, I realized everything was being rushed towards the ending. I didn't really like it.The "open world" aspects are almost nil, and the game is rather short. It has 2 "big" areas where you'll spend most of your playtime in, then a very small stealth section, and finally the last stage, which is awfully paced (a few empty corridors and easy puzzles), probably because of the rushed ending.All in all, the game is rather entertaining, but beware of its cons.

Now, would I recommend this for the PC? ....Not necessarily, it is horribly ported. Every time I launched the game it said my graphics card drivers were out of date (they weren't) Apparently, if you run this on a newer machine, the game can't recognize your graphics card and will just pop that error up every time you launch. You can click through it to boot the game up, though. Before you do that, I would suggest going into the advanced settings (not ingame), going into the manual compatibility settings and disabling HW Vertex Processing: it's job is to bug your game out with random polygons and artifacts that make the game unplayable. From what I've read, this happens to a lot of people.Another problem with the port, this game was designed for a controller, yet there's no controller support. If you're like me, you're going to need to faff about extensively with the control settings to get the game marginally comfortable to play. One thing that I couldn't fix was how both the mouse and WSAD keys sent the same commands when you're in a vehicle and it screws with the camera. All in all, while I got through the game fine enough, it felt like I was limping the whole way because of the poor controls.The game itself, though, was wonderful. As I took in the music, characters, and setting of the game I was sad that this never got the trilogy it promised to be.
